messages: a9b33350543d7a8a9f87d237fa6170f7 (08:43): does anyone here have a moment to test out a wysiwyg script i have, and see what you think of it?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (08:48): was this printed by a Microsoft employee? http://www.flickr.com/photos/8554702@N05/4080900839/in/set-72157622749234808/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Indeed, if you look further in the logs you'll see I found the email from Philip` that changed it.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (09:09): Well like I said there's no posible way we can split text in about half our backends since they don't have the concept of text nodes
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (09:09): And I think it will be an enormous pain to get this right for the other half of our backends (the useless ones)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:12): Indeed.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:13): And implementations in lower level languages, such as those used in browsers, can simply support mutable strings and just have O(n) behaviour.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (09:18): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Well that seems like a rather unfair requirement since browsers could have chosen to use immutable strings already

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (09:20): (In principle if you can change the string implementation, you could do something like http://bugs.python.org/issue1569040 although note that patch hasn't been accepted :( )
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (09:20): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I don't know who printed it but I do believe Paul Cotton brandished it at some points
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (09:20): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: is there a requirement in the HTML5 parser to sometimes have multiple adjacent text nodes?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:28): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: IIRC, it's at least permitted when text is foster-parented
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:29): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: ok. good enough supporting evidence for the rumor that MS employees like to print specs.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (09:29): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I was not aware of such a rumor
1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b (09:30): I have a colleague who likes to print unified diffs that he needs to review
1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b (09:30): he reviews them with a pen!
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (09:33): if developers used the online version, people could mine the whatwg.org logs to figure out what was being implemented
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:44): is on a train back to Shinjuku, checking the logs to see if he's missed anything interesting
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:45): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Everything.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (09:48): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/tokenization.html#insert-a-character Note the example
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (09:49): specifically the <table>A<tr>B one
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (09:49): that's some wacky examples
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:58): fwiw, I think it was one of the X3D guys who printed out the copy of the spec, and for benign reasons (not for purposes of it being used as a prop)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (09:59): I don't think the use as a prop was malicious
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:00): is finding that the certain eyboard eys on his aptop don't wor any onger after train went around a curve and beverage spashed down on his eyboard
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:07): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: btw, I guess you saw that the ruby support got committed
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:08): having a hard time wording things without using characters between i and m

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:12): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: I'm wondering what my chances are of convincing somebody to become editor for the CSS Ruby spec so that we can move that forward faster and get it supported too
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:12): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: don't look at me :-)
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:13): there you go, copy/pastable
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:13): used to google for ~ when first got an italian keyboard mac
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:14): maybe I can as Mr, Steiner
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:14): he understands the issues better than anybody by now, perhaps
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (10:17): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Ruby support got committed into what? WebKit?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:18): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: yeah
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:18): does WebKit support Ruby as an addition to CSS or as a non-CSS extension to layout?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I thin it does not support CSS Ruby yet at all
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:19): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: already in Webkit nightlies
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:19): dunno about Chrome
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:22): (thanks to c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 for the the l's and k's)
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:22): careful, don't use 'em all at once
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:28): I have a new appreciation for them
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:28): the letter 'j' in contrast seems mostly unnecessary
